On the Continued Absence of Mr. Barnaby Finch (2018–Present)

Barnaby left on a Tuesday in September with two sketchbooks, a bag of willow charcoal, and a note that read only: “The true weight of the weeping face.” I have continued the catalogue in his absence, because someone must, and because stopping would mean admitting he isn’t coming back, and I am not yet willing to concede that point.

:weeping_joy_gentleman:
A bewhiskered fellow overcome with such mirth that his monocle steams.
Perpetually Out of Stock

“This is the one they all want, and the one I refuse to finish. The modern version has become a mask—people affix it to sentences that contain no joy whatsoever. How does one illustrate a laugh that means nothing? I have attempted seventeen drafts. Each one looks too sincere.”

“The thumbs up is the conversational equivalent of a closed door. It says: I have received your message and I will not be engaging further. Our version at least has the decency to look you in the eye while declining to respond.”

A heart rendered with anatomical precision and botanical flourishes.

“Everyone sends hearts. No one means them. I drew ours with visible ventricles because love should be specific and slightly uncomfortable to look at directly, like the sun, or the person you actually love.”

:pensive_scholar:
A scholar mid-rumination, pipe in hand, one eyebrow operating independently.

“People use the thinking face to indicate they are about to disagree with you. The Victorians had a far more elegant solution: they simply disagreed, at length, in writing, and mailed it three days later when the fury had mellowed into something publishable.”

:memento_mori:
A memento mori so lavish it made three test users weep openly.

“The skull emoji means ‘I am dying of laughter,’ which is a statement so profoundly divorced from its literal meaning that it deserves its own wing in a museum of linguistic collapse. Ours simply means what it has always meant: you will die. You are welcome.”

:conspiratorial_lady:
A lady of uncertain virtue sharing a confidence you didn’t ask for.

“The wink is the last honest emoji. It admits upfront that something unspoken is happening. Every other emoji pretends to be transparent. The wink has the decency to confess it is performing. I respect it enormously and drew her with Clementine’s jawline, though she hasn’t noticed.”

On the Degradation of True Sentiment

From the collected writings of B. Finch, originally published 14 March 2016

“Consider the thumbs up. A gesture so ancient it once decided whether a man lived or died in a Roman amphitheatre. It has been flattened into a yellow circle and deployed to acknowledge receipt of a dinner reservation. We have taken the vocabulary of life and death and used it to say ‘okay.’ This is not efficiency. This is surrender dressed as convenience.” — Barnaby Finch, “On the Degradation of True Sentiment,” victorianemojis.com/journal, 2016
▲ 247 · PenNibPaula · 16 Mar 2016

I sent a winking face to my therapist last week and she brought it up in our next session as “an avoidance behaviour.” Barnaby is right. The wink is doing more emotional labour than any of us are prepared to admit.

▲ 183 · InkwellRegrets · 17 Mar 2016

Counterpoint: my grandmother sends me the prayer hands emoji every Sunday and it makes me cry every single time. Some of us are communicating just fine, Barnaby. Not everyone needs twelve pages of copperplate to say “I love you.”

▲ 91 · GlovesOff1847 · 22 Mar 2016

I have replaced every emoji in my phone with Victorian Emojis stickers and I can confirm that nobody texts me anymore. Mission accomplished? I think? I feel something and I’m not sure what the shortcode for it is.

Ed. note, C. Blackwood: Barnaby wrote this three days before we launched the thumbs up conversion. He spent the entire launch party staring at his phone, receiving congratulatory thumbs-up emojis from friends, and muttering. I should have known then.

A skull wreathed in forget-me-nots, resting on a stack of unread letters, a pocket watch stopped at 3:14 AM, a candle guttering.

REJECTED: “Three testers wept. One requested a print. None understood it meant ‘I’m dead’ as in ‘that joke was funny.’”

Four guests in evening dress, standing at a respectful distance, one raising a glass of sherry approximately 15 degrees above horizontal.

The Licensing Agreement (Abridged)

Victorian Emojis Standard Use Licence, Revision 7.2, Last Amended by C. Blackwood, 2023

  1. The licensee shall employ Victorian Emojis solely for correspondence of a sincere or earnestly satirical nature. Frivolous deployment, including but not limited to: marketing materials for energy drinks, cryptocurrency announcements, and gender-reveal communications, is expressly prohibited.
  2. The “Weeping Gentleman” (:weeping_gentleman:) shall under no circumstances appear in promotional materials for products of a cheerful disposition, including but not limited to: greeting cards, theme parks, and motivational podcasts.
  3. All intellectual property created by Mr. Barnaby Finch remains held in trust pending his return or confirmed demise, whichever occurs first. In the interim, Ms. Clementine Blackwood retains sole curatorial authority, a responsibility she neither requested nor enjoys.
  4. The licensee acknowledges that no Victorian Emoji can fully replace the act of writing an actual letter to someone you love. This licence grants the right to approximate sentiment, not to achieve it.
  5. Redistribution of the “Conspiratorial Lady” wink on dating applications requires a supplementary fee of £4.50 and a brief written statement confirming the sender’s intentions are “at minimum, ambiguous in a dignified fashion.”
  6. Any dispute arising from this licence shall be settled by a panel of three: one calligrapher, one semiotician, and one person who has recently been hurt by an emoji. Their decision is final.

Testimonials & The Inkwell

“I have been using Victorian Emojis exclusively in my correspondence since 2016. My wife left me. My colleagues think I am eccentric. My pen pal in Shropshire, however, says my letters have never been more ‘achingly precise,’ and frankly that is the only review that matters. I sent a Weeping Gentleman to my mother on her birthday and she called me, in tears, to ask if I was alright. It was the longest conversation we have had in eleven years.”

— Col. (Ret.) Geoffrey Stanhope, Historical Reenactment Society of the West Midlands, Member since 2015

Has Anyone Heard From Barnaby? (Pinned, Locked) · 312 replies

Here is what I know after six years of drawing feelings for strangers: none of us are saying what we mean. Not with emojis, not with letters, not with twelve-page Victorian epistles sealed with wax and drenched in lavender. We keep building better vehicles for sincerity and then driving them straight past the person we meant to stop for. But we keep trying. Every little yellow circle is someone reaching out and falling short and reaching out again, and if that isn’t the most human thing I’ve ever seen, I don’t know what is. I’ll keep drawing. You keep sending. Maybe one day the picture and the feeling will be the same thing.
